title: 106_s2748
content: The Act may be cited as the "Russian-American Trust and Cooperation Act of 2000". The Congress finds that the Russian Federation operates an intelligence facility at Lourdes, Cuba, leased for $100-300 million a year. The facility covers a 28 square-mile area with over 1,500 Russian personnel. The Lourdes facility in Cuba is operated by the Russian Federation as an intelligence station. It covers a 28 square-mile area with over 1,500 Russian personnel. The base has tracking dishes and a satellite system used for intercepting communications. The facility has been reported to gather sensitive information about United States military operations. Academic studies highlight the threat posed by the Lourdes espionage station in collecting personal information about the United States. The Lourdes facility in Cuba, operated by the Russian Federation, collects personal information about United States citizens and engages in cyberwarfare. The facility's operational significance grew after a directive from Russian President Boris Yeltsin in 1996, with an estimated $3 billion spent on its operation and modernization. Former US officials confirm reports on the facility's activities. The Russian Federation has spent over $3 billion on the operation and modernization of the Lourdes facility in Cuba. Former US officials confirm the expansion and upgrade of the facility, with a high-ranking Russian military delegation visiting Cuba to discuss its operation. Prohibition on bilateral debt rescheduling and forgiveness for the Russian Federation. Prohibition on rescheduling or forgiving Russian Federation's bilateral debt by the US until Russia closes its intelligence facility in Cuba. President can waive this if deemed necessary for national interest. The President can waive the prohibition on rescheduling or forgiving Russian Federation's debt if necessary for national interest. The waiver must be certified to relevant committees and include detailed facts supporting the decision. Periodic reports must be submitted every 180 days after the certification. The President may submit a classified written certification if deemed appropriate. Every 180 days after the certification, a report must be sent to the relevant committees detailing the extent of meeting the requirements. SEC. 4. REPORT ON THE CLOSING OF THE INTELLIGENCE FACILITY AT LOURDES, CUBA. The President must submit a report every 120 days detailing Russia's actions to close the intelligence facility in Cuba and efforts by US agencies to verify these actions.
